content.body:
> <@jarhar:matrix.org> a friend of mine is asking about how to make use of native context menus on the web, and told me that there was an old now removed thing in firefox which included the menuitem element. are yall aware of any current work or plans to make this kind of thing possible?

See https://platform.html5.org/history/webapps/r4636.html#context-menus ‚Äî not as far as current work, but just as far as what the spec once had before it was eventually removed (due to lack of implementor interest).
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @jarhar:matrix.org
a friend of mine is asking about how to make use of native context menus on the web, and told me that there was an old now removed thing in firefox which included the menuitem element. are yall aware of any current work or plans to make this kind of thing possible?
See https://platform.html5.org/history/webapps/r4636.html#context-menus ‚Äî not as far as current work, but just as far as what the spec once had before it was eventually removed (due to lack of implementor interest).

content.body: was there any issues that implementors brought up?
At this point I don‚Äôt recall. Would need to do some archaeology. Anne or Domenic might remember more
I just now looked through the commit history, but can‚Äôt even find the commit that removed it‚Ä¶
found https://github.com/whatwg/html/commit/e7e8c88e
* <del>I just now looked through the commit history, but can‚Äôt even find the commit that removed it‚Ä¶</del>
content.formatted_body: * <del>I just now looked through the commit history, but can‚Äôt even find the commit that removed it‚Ä¶</del>

m.new_content.body: <del>I just now looked through the commit history, but can‚Äôt even find the commit that removed it‚Ä¶</del>
m.new_content.formatted_body: <del>I just now looked through the commit history, but can‚Äôt even find the commit that removed it‚Ä¶</del>

content.body: ‚Ä¶which links to https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=87553&desc=2#c64

> - There is doubt whether the API is well designed.
> - This may not be a high enough priority right now. Part of the team is responsible for implementing new "capabilities". Reaching outside the content area and contributing items to the browser's context menu is a new capability. yuzus, tkent and I are not on the capabilities part of the team; they are busy bringing web developers other new capabilities. They should be heavily involved in the decision to implement this but they can't right now.
> - It is hard to prioritize for other reasons. For example, this feature only exists in Firefox, so we're not making interoperability better by implementing this.
content.formatted_body:
• There is doubt whether the API is well designed.
  • This may not be a high enough priority right now. Part of the team is responsible for implementing new "capabilities". Reaching outside the content area and contributing items to the browser's context menu is a new capability. yuzus, tkent and I are not on the capabilities part of the team; they are busy bringing web developers other new capabilities. They should be heavily involved in the decision to implement this but they can't right now.
  • It is hard to prioritize for other reasons. For example, this feature only exists in Firefox, so we're not making interoperability better by implementing this.

content.body: ‚Ä¶for which one way of reading it is, _‚Äúbecause WebKit hasn‚Äôt implemented it, we don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs enough of a priority‚Äù_
content.formatted_body: ‚Ä¶for which one way of reading it is, ‚Äúbecause WebKit hasn‚Äôt implemented it, we don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs enough of a priority‚Äù

content.body: thank you for finding this!
cheers
akaster: oh wow, file an issue? I guess we should just update the spec then.
content.formatted_body: akaster: oh wow, file an issue? I guess we should just update the spec then.

content.body: Sure thing! I was wondering if maybe my interpretation of "HTML Element" was wrong given how they all agreed üòÖ
I made issue 9766 for this
Thanks! (HTML element definitely means HTML namespace.)

> <@jyasskin:matrix.org> The team working on HTTPS auto-upgrades would like to get https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1655 into Fetch. What's their next step toward merging it?

I'd be happy to help with some editorial reviews if annevk gives a green light for the general direction of the feature etc
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @jyasskin:matrix.org
The team working on HTTPS auto-upgrades would like to get https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1655 into Fetch. What's their next step toward merging it?
I'd be happy to help with some editorial reviews if annevk gives a green light for the general direction of the feature etc

content.body: about the _‚Äúdocument.open() does not change document's URL (active but not fully active document‚Äù_ test case at https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/db6e5032915eb0dcb1d8b8b249488055378245fd/html/webappapis/dynamic-markup-insertion/opening-the-input-stream/url.window.js#L28 : in light of https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/4076 ‚Äî¬†and specifically the requirement _‚ÄúA [Location](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/nav-history-apis.html#location) object has an associated url, which is this [Location](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/nav-history-apis.html#location) object's [relevant Document](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/nav-history-apis.html#relevant-document)'s [URL](https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-document-url), if this [Location](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/nav-history-apis.html#location) object's [relevant Document](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/nav-history-apis.html#relevant-document) is non-null, and [about:blank](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/infrastructure.html#about:blank) otherwise‚Äù_ ‚Äî shouldn‚Äôt that test be updated to change the assert there to `assert_equals(childWin.location.href, "about:blank")`?
content.formatted_body: about the ‚Äúdocument.open() does not change document's URL (active but not fully active document‚Äù test case at https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/db6e5032915eb0dcb1d8b8b249488055378245fd/html/webappapis/dynamic-markup-insertion/opening-the-input-stream/url.window.js#L28 : in light of https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/4076 ‚Äî and specifically the requirement ‚ÄúA Location object has an associated url, which is this Location object's relevant Document's URL, if this Location object's relevant Document is non-null, and about:blank otherwise‚Äù ‚Äî shouldn‚Äôt that test be updated to change the assert there to assert_equals(childWin.location.href, "about:blank")?

m.new_content.formatted_body: annevk: about the ‚Äúdocument.open() does not change document's URL (active but not fully active document)‚Äù test case at https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/db6e5032915eb0dcb1d8b8b249488055378245fd/html/webappapis/dynamic-markup-insertion/opening-the-input-stream/url.window.js#L28 : in light of https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/4076 ‚Äî and specifically the requirement ‚ÄúA Location object has an associated url, which is this Location object's relevant Document's URL, if this Location object's relevant Document is non-null, and about:blank otherwise‚Äù ‚Äî shouldn‚Äôt that test be updated to change the assert there to assert_equals(childWin.location.href, "about:blank")?

content.body: sideshowbarker: I'm not sure that's accurate, relevant Document is childFrame.contentDocument, which is non-null, right?

content.body: (Tracked in https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18110 for now.)

> <@annevk:matrix.org> sideshowbarker: I'm not sure that's accurate, relevant Document is childFrame.contentDocument, which is non-null, right?

Yeah, seems so ‚Äî and that‚Äôs also what I had thought, but WebKit is the only UA to have implemented that spec change, and WebKit returns `about:blank` there. So it appears to be a bug in WebKit, caused by the Location code not having the Frame object that it should have.

Take a look at https://searchfox.org/wubkat/source/Source/WebCore/page/Location.cpp#53-54. That entire code assumes there‚Äôs a single `frame()` Frame object that it gets the location from. But for that test case, it‚Äôs null. So I guess changing  the `src` value of that iframe either causes the `childDoc` to be prematurely completely disassociated from `childFrame`, or else that `childFrame` gets prematurely destroyed.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
sideshowbarker: I'm not sure that's accurate, relevant Document is childFrame.contentDocument, which is non-null, right?

Yeah, seems so ‚Äî and that‚Äôs also what I had thought, but WebKit is the only UA to have implemented that spec change, and WebKit returns about:blank there. So it appears to be a bug in WebKit, caused by the Location code not having the Frame object that it should have.

Take a look at https://searchfox.org/wubkat/source/Source/WebCore/page/Location.cpp#53-54. That entire code assumes there‚Äôs a single frame() Frame object that it gets the location from. But for that test case, it‚Äôs null. So I guess changing the src value of that iframe either causes the childDoc to be prematurely completely disassociated from childFrame, or else that childFrame gets prematurely destroyed.

content.body: Does anyone know how you find out if indexing a spec got stuck? XHR still doesn't pick up terms we introduced in HTML two days ago.

sideshowbarker: are you saying `Frame` is 1:1 with `Document`? I'm not familiar with how this stuff is implemented in browsers unfortunately.
